results.p: Sep 1, 2024 — 1. a : to bring together : blend Even more often, outsiders conflate the couple, and credit them with each other's characteristics.
7 days ago — to combine two or more separate things, especially pieces of text, to form a whole: She conflated the three plays to produce a fresh new work.

results.p: 2 days ago — If you conflate two or more descriptions or ideas, or if they conflate, you combine them in order to produce a single one.
results.t: CONFLATE definition and meaning | Collins English ...

results.p: Other forms: conflated; conflating; conflates. Conflate is a more formal way to say "mix together," and it's typically used for texts or ideas.
Conflation is the merging of two or more sets of information, texts, ideas, or opinions into one, often in error. Conflation is defined as 'fusing blending' ...
verb (used with object) , con·flat·ed, con·flat·ing. to fuse into one entity; merge: to conflate dissenting voices into one protest.
Sep 1, 2024 — 1. as in to confuse to fail to differentiate (a thing) from something similar or related be careful not to conflate gossip with real news.
results.t: CONFLATE Synonyms: 71 Similar and Opposite Words

results.p: Feb 9, 2015 — “Conflate” is “to bring together” (as in “fuse”) and “confuse,” or “to combine (as two readings of a text) into a composite whole.”
What does the verb conflate mean? There are three meanings listed in OED's entry for the verb conflate, one of which is labelled obsolete. See 'Meaning & use' ...
